factoid: Hélène told the count that she must look after the count's daughters.
Hélène told the count that she is not staying here long this time.
Hélène told the count that she will try to amuse the count's daughters.
Hélène had already heard much about the count in Petersburg.
Hélène wanted to get to know the count.
Hélène had heard about the count from her page, Drubetskóy.
Hélène asked the count whether the count is getting married.
Hélène also heard from Prince Andrew Bolkónski, who is a friend of the count's husband.
Hélène implied that she knows of Prince Andrew Bolkónski's relation to Natásha.
Hélène asked that one of the young ladies come into her box for the rest of the performance.
Natásha moved over to Hélène's box.
The third act scene represented a palace with many candles burning.
The third act scene had pictures of knights with short beards hung on the walls.
In the middle of the third act scene stood what were probably a king and a queen.
The king waved his right arm.
The king sang something badly.
The king sat down on a crimson throne.
The maiden had been first wearing white, then light blue, now wore only a smock.
The maiden stood beside the throne with her hair down.
The maiden sang something mournfully, addressing the queen.
The king waved his arm severely.
Men and women with bare legs came in from both sides and began dancing together.
The violins played very shrill and merrily.
One of the women with thick bare legs and thin arms separated from the others.
That woman went behind the wings.
That woman adjusted her bodice.
That woman returned to the middle of the stage.
That woman began jumping and striking one foot rapidly against the other.
In the stalls everyone clapped and shouted "bravo!".
One of the men went into a corner of the stage.
The cymbals and horns in the orchestra struck up more loudly.
The man with bare legs jumped very high and waved his feet about very rapidly.
The man with bare legs was Duport.
Duport received sixty thousand rubles a year for this art.
Everybody in the stalls, boxes, and galleries began clapping and shouting with all their might.
The man stopped and began smiling and bowing to all sides.
Other men and women danced with bare legs.
The king again shouted to the sound of music.
They all began singing.
Suddenly a storm came on.
Chromatic scales and diminished sevenths were heard in the orchestra.
Everyone ran off, dragging one of their number away.
The curtain dropped.
Once more there was a terrible noise and clatter among the audience.
Everyone began shouting "Duport! Duport! Duport!".
Natásha no longer thought this strange.
Natásha looked about with pleasure, smiling joyfully.
Hélène asked Natásha "Isn't Duport delightful?".
Natásha replied "Oh, yes.".
During the entr'acte a whiff of cold air came into Hélène's box.
The door opened into Hélène's box.
Anatole entered Hélène's box, stooping.
Anatole tried not to brush against anyone.
Hélène said "Let me introduce my brother to you.".
Hélène's eyes shifted uneasily from Natásha to Anatole.
Natásha turned her pretty little head toward Anatole.
Natásha smiled at Anatole over her bare shoulder.
Anatole was as handsome at close quarters as at a distance.
Anatole sat down beside Natásha.
Anatole told Natásha that he had long wished to have this happiness.
Anatole had long wished to have this happiness ever since the Narýshkins' ball.
Anatole had the well-remembered pleasure of seeing Natásha at the Narýshkins' ball.
Kurágin was much more sensible and simple with women than among men.
Kurágin talked boldly and naturally.
Natásha was strangely and agreeably struck by the fact that there was nothing formidable in Kurágin.
Natásha was struck by the fact that Kurágin had a smile that was most naïve, cheerful, and good-natured.
Kurágin asked Natásha her opinion of the performance.
Kurágin told Natásha that at a previous performance Semënova had fallen down on the stage.
Kurágin addressed Natásha as "Countess".
Kurágin told Natásha that they are getting up a costume tournament.
Kurágin told Natásha that she ought to take part in the costume tournament.
Kurágin told Natásha that it will be great fun.
Kurágin told Natásha that they shall all meet at the Karágins'.
Kurágin told Natásha to come to the costume tournament.
Kurágin said "No! Really, eh?".
